message.content:
A trombone is a brass instrument that produces sound by blowing air through a mouthpiece and adjusting the length of the tubing with a slide. 
It typically has a shiny, metallic appearance and may be coated in a clear lacquer to protect the brass. 
The main body of the trombone is curved and often has a slender shape with a larger bell at the end. 
Along the tubing, you can see distinct tuning slides and a larger bell at the end. 
Trombones are commonly used in classical and jazz music, as well as in marching bands and other musical ensembles. 
They can typically be found in orchestras, concert bands, music classrooms, and music stores. 
Visual elements that distinguish trombones from other instruments include the elongated slide and their characteristic bell shape.
